footnotes: Gr. koinōnia (communion, participation) indicates real sharing in Christ's body and blood, not mere symbolic association.
St. John Chrysostom, Hom. on 1 Cor. 24: 'What is the bread? The body of Christ. What do communicants become? The body of Christ.'
'This is my body' (touto mou estin to sōma)—the demonstrative 'this' refers to what Christ holds, which He declares to be His body.
Guilt 'of the body and blood' presupposes their real presence; one cannot profane a mere symbol.
St. John Chrysostom, Hom. on 1 Cor. 27: 'Consider how indignant you are against the traitor... You too are guilty of the same crimes.'
'Not discerning the body' (mē diakrinōn to sōma) indicates failure to recognize Christ's real presence, not merely failing to appreciate a symbol.
'Saved, yet so as by fire' describes purification after death for those who built with 'wood, hay, stubble'—works of imperfection though not mortal sin.
St. Augustine, Enchiridion 69: 'Some believers pass through a purifying fire, suffering losses but attaining salvation.'
Council of Florence (1439): This verse supports the doctrine that souls 'are cleansed by purgatorial punishments after death.'
Baptism 'for the dead' presupposes prayers and practices for the deceased can benefit them—incompatible with immediate heaven or hell for all.
